The Southerner (1945) is an American drama film directed by acclaimed French filmmaker Jean Renoir, best known for cinematic masterpieces such as The Rules of the Game (1939) and Grand Illusion (1937). This independent production, released by United Artists, adapts George Sessions Perryâ€™s 1941 novel Hold Autumn in Your Hand into a poignant tale of resilience, poverty, and dignity in rural America. Presented here in a fully restored and colorized edition, this public domain classic gains renewed accessibility for modern audiences in the United States, Europe, and worldwide.

Plot Summary:
The story follows Sam Tucker (Zachary Scott), a poor but determined Texas sharecropper who dreams of achieving independence for his family. Leaving behind the security of tenant farming, Sam acquires his own small plot of land with his devoted wife Nona (Betty Field), their two children, and his strong-willed grandmother (Beulah Bondi). Despite their optimism, the Tuckers face relentless hardships: failed crops, sickness, poverty, and the unforgiving realities of nature.

As Sam struggles to cultivate cotton and make his land prosper, he faces not only natural obstacles like drought and floods but also the skepticism of neighbors and his familyâ€™s doubts. His perseverance and vision clash with the constant possibility of failure. The film builds toward a conclusion that captures both the hope and despair of rural life, making The Southerner one of Renoirâ€™s most humanistic and emotionally raw works.

The Southerner is widely regarded as one of Renoirâ€™s greatest American films and one of the finest depictions of rural hardship in 1940s cinema. It earned three Academy Award nominations: Best Director (Jean Renoir), Best Sound, and Best Original Music Score. Despite critical acclaim, the film was controversial in the American South upon release, with some objecting to its portrayal of poverty. Today, it is celebrated for its raw honesty, Renoirâ€™s poetic realism, and its unflinching look at resilience against economic struggle.
